Jeb Hensarling [chairman of the committee] presiding.</hearing-info> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker=""> Present: Representatives Hensarling, Royce, Lucas, Pearce, Posey, Luetkemeyer, Huizenga, Duffy, Stivers, Hultgren, Ross, Pittenger, Wagner, Barr, Rothfus, Messer, Tipton, Williams, Poliquin, Love, Hill, Emmer, Zeldin, Trott, Loudermilk, Mooney, MacArthur, Davidson, Budd, Kustoff, Tenney, Hollingsworth, Waters, Maloney, Velazquez, Sherman, Meeks, Capuano, Clay, Lynch, Scott, Cleaver, Ellison, Perlmutter, Himes, Foster, Kildee, Delaney, Sinema, Beatty, Heck, Vargas, Gottheimer, and Gonzalez. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Hensarling</speaker> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">The committee will come to order.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">Without objection, the Chair is authorized to declare a recess of the committee at any time, and all members will have 5 legislative days within which to submit extraneous materials to the chair for inclusion in the record.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">The hearing is entitled ``Examining the Equifax Data Breach.''</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">I now recognize myself for 3-1/2 minutes to give an opening statement.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">On September 7, Equifax announced what it called a, quote, ``cybersecurity incident'' at its business that potentially affects 145 million U.S. consumers--nearly half of all Americans. In other words, if you are hearing my voice, you are either the victim of the breach or you know someone who is. That is how massive this breach was.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">The criminals got basically everything they need to steal your identity, open credit card accounts in your name, and cause you untold frustration and financial calamity. This may be the most harmful failure to protect private consumer information the world has ever seen.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">The company's response to this breach has left much to be desired. For weeks, Equifax failed to disclose the breach to consumers and its shareholders. It provided confusing information about whether people were victims of the breach or not.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">And, beyond belief, senior executives sold their Equifax shares after the company knew of the breach and before the company disclosed the breach. I trust the Justice Department and Securities Exchange Commission (SEC) will get to the bottom of this.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">Clearly, action by the Federal Trade Commission, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, and potentially other regulators is required. Congress must ensure that Federal law enforcement and Federal regulators do their jobs so justice can be served and victims are made whole.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">We must thoroughly examine if our agencies in statutes like Gramm-Leach-Bliley, the Fair Credit Reporting Act, and UDAAP are up to the job.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">In this era, big data, large-scale security breaches unfortunately are becoming all too common. By the increasing frequency and sophistication of cyber attacks, this clearly demands heightened vigilance and enhanced efforts to safeguard consumers.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">Protecting consumers obviously starts with requiring effective measures to prevent data breaches in the first place. Given the Federal Government's own poor track record when it comes to protecting personal information witness the SEC and the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) hacks as two recent examples.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">We must be cautious about attempts to never let a good crisis go to waste and impose a Washington-forced technology solution that may be antiquated as soon as it is imposed. However, I do believe that we need to ensure we have a consistent national standard for both data security and breach notification in order to better protect our consumers, hold companies accountable, and assure that this affair does not repeat itself.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">Our committee passed such legislation nearly 2 years ago, the bipartisan Data Security Act. The need to revisit that legislation and, where necessary, improve upon it should be obvious to all. The status quo is clearly failing consumers and leaving them extremely vulnerable.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">So I look forward to working with members of both sides of the aisle and working with the Administration to ensure that Americans across the country will be protected and will no longer have to lose sleep over the kind of breaches that we are discussing today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">I yield back the balance of my time.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Chairman Hensarling"> I now recognize the Ranking Member of the Committee, the gentlelady from California, for 3 minutes. </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. Waters</speaker> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Ms. Waters">Thank you, Mr. Chairman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Ms. Waters">The massive breach at Equifax and the company's subsequent failures are a lapse on a scale we have never seen before. Equifax's failure to safeguard consumer data is all the more egregious because the impacted customers never chose to do business with Equifax.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Ms. Waters">And because of the broken business models of our country's credit reporting agencies, these consumers can't end their relationship with Equifax. They can't shop around for a better deal. They are literally stuck with this company.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Ms. Waters">So I am very interested in what Equifax will do moving forward to provide full redress for all of those who have been harmed. I am also interested in why Equifax has sent this committee a witness today without the authority to commit Equifax to future action.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Ms. Waters">The members of this committee need to hear not just about what has happened but also about what Equifax plans to do moving forward. I already know that this hearing won't answer all of the questions, and I and other members would like to know more.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Ms. Waters">This is why committee Democrats are requesting a minority day hearing to get more answers to the questions surrounding not only this breach but also its impact on consumers and solutions for consumers moving forward.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="Ms. Waters">For example, I, for one, would like to make sure that credit reporting agencies do not inappropriately profit off of this incident by exploiting consumers' legitimate fears. Now is not the time to focus on how to sell consumers more products. Now is the time to fix what has been broken.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="Ms. Waters">But this breach and Equifax's woeful response are just the tip of the iceberg. The whole credit reporting system needs a complete overhaul. That is why I introduced H.R. 3755, the Comprehensive Consumer Credit Reporting Reform Act. This legislation would, among other things, shift the burden of removing credit report mistakes to credit reporting agencies and away from consumers.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="28" speaker="Ms. Waters">And my bill would also shrink the importance of credit reports in our lives by limiting the use of credit reports in employment checks and limiting when CRAs can collect information on consumers. It is time to end the strangledhold that Equifax, TransUnion, and Experian have on our consumers' lives.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="29" speaker="Ms. Waters"> Mr. Chairman, I yield back. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Hensarling</speaker> <paragraph paraId="30" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">The gentlelady yields back.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="31" speaker="Chairman Hensarling"> The Chair now recognizes the gentleman from Missouri, Mr. Luetkemeyer, the Chairman from our Financial Institutions Subcommittee for 1-1/2 minutes. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Luetkemeyer</speaker> <paragraph paraId="32" speaker="Mr. Luetkemeyer">Thank you, Mr. Chairman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="33" speaker="Mr. Luetkemeyer">Mr. Smith, I know you have sat before several committees this week, and I trust you have heard the anger from Congress and the American people. This is not just incompetence on the part of you and your company but also negligence and disregard for the law and for consumers.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="34" speaker="Mr. Luetkemeyer">There is a failure on the part of you, your board, and your senior management, and your failures have impacted more than one-third of the American people. What is most egregious to me is that the American people's data had potentially been compromised, had to wait more than a month to find out about it.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="35" speaker="Mr. Luetkemeyer">The American public deserves better. They deserve prompt notification so they can safeguard their identity. They deserve a system that effectively and efficiently notifies them, not one that has slowed down because of turf wars, regulatory complex, or fear of litigation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="36" speaker="Mr. Luetkemeyer">I believe it is now time to move forward, and we need to find solutions to this problem. I hope that if one good thing comes from this yet another major data breach, it is that the American consumers can finally get a system that works for them.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="37" speaker="Mr. Luetkemeyer">I Chair the Financial Institutions Subcommittee that is going to have oversight over this data breach and a security informational-type of bill, and I can assure you we are going to try and look very thoroughly at this incident as others drum up some ways to protect the American consumers.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="38" speaker="Mr. Luetkemeyer"> Mr. Chairman, with that, I yield back. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Hensarling</speaker> <paragraph paraId="39" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">The gentleman yields back.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="40" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">The Chair now recognizes the gentleman from Missouri, Mr. Clay, the Ranking Member of the Financial Institutions Subcommittee for 1 minute. Apparently he is not here.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="41" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">We then will go to the gentleman from Michigan, who also appears not to be here.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="42" speaker="Chairman Hensarling"> The gentleman from Minnesota, Mr. Ellison, is recognized for 1 minute. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Ellison</speaker> <paragraph paraId="43" speaker="Mr. Ellison">I would like to thank the Chair and Ranking Member for this important hearing.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="44" speaker="Mr. Ellison">A lot has been said about the Equifax breach and a lot of the same things will be repeated today, but there are a few things that I think we have to bear in mind: One is that Equifax and two other big players in this industry of credit reporting dominate basically the whole field.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="45" speaker="Mr. Ellison">As members of this committee know, I have been quite concerned about market concentration. I believe Equifax is just too big. It needs to be reduced in size. We need to increase competition and we need--and if Equifax had to worry about a real competitor, I believe they would be better at safeguarding the data of consumers.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="46" speaker="Mr. Ellison">It is the fact that markets have concentrated it so high that other than TransUnion and Experian, Equifax doesn't have to worry about much competition--that they can be lax with the data of people.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="47" speaker="Mr. Ellison"> I look forward to the gentleman talking about some issues that I think are very important. I know that there has been some movement in the area of--well, I will leave that to you for the rest of the questioning. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Hensarling</speaker> <paragraph paraId="48" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">The time of the gentleman has expired.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="49" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">The Chair now recognizes the gentlelady from New York, Mrs. Maloney, Ranking Member of the Capital Markets Subcommittee for 1 minute.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="50" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">Mrs. Maloney. Mr. Smith, Equifax was not just a breach of security. It was not just a massive, huge database breach. It was a breach in the trust of the American people in your company.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="51" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">We have the best markets in the world, and I believe that our markets run more on trust than it does on capital. So a breach of trust is something our markets cannot tolerate.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="52" speaker="Chairman Hensarling"> I join my colleagues in being committed to finding procedures going forward that this does not happen again, and that the law is enforced against those who breach and break the law. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Hensarling</speaker> <paragraph paraId="53" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">The time of the gentlelady has expired.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="54" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">Today we will receive the testimony of Mr. Richard Smith, who is the former CEO and Chairman of Equifax and adviser to the interim CEO. Prior to September 26 of this year, Mr. Smith had been the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Equifax since 2005. Before joining Equifax, Mr. Smith held various management positions at General Electric where he worked for 22 years.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="55" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">Without objection, the witness' written statement will be made part of the record.</paragraph>
Hearing.Statement: <opening>STATEMENT OF RICHARD F. SMITH</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="RICHARD F. SMITH"> Mr. Smith, you are now recognized for 5 minutes to give an oral presentation of your testimony. Thank you. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Smith</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Smith">Thank you. Thank you Chairman Hensarling, Ranking Member Waters, and the honorable Members of the committee. Thank you for allowing me to come before you today to testify. Again, I am Rick Smith, and for the past 12 years, I have had the honor of serving as Chairman and CEO of Equifax.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Smith">Over the past month or so, I have had the opportunity to talk to many American consumers and read their letters, those impacted and not impacted alike, and understand their anger and frustration that we have caused at Equifax.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Smith">This criminal attack on our data occurred on my watch, and I take full responsibility for that attack as the CEO. I want every American and everyone here to understand that I am deeply apologetic and sorry that this breach occurred; and that, I also want the American public to know that Equifax is committed to dedicate our energy and time going forward to making things right.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Smith">Americans have a right to know how this happened, and today I am prepared to testify about what I learned and what I did about this incident while CEO of the company, and also what I know about the incident as a result of being briefed by the company's ongoing investigation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Smith">We now know that this criminal attack was made possible by a combination of a human error and a technological error. The human error involved the failure to apply a patch to a dispute portal in March 2017. The technological error involved a scanner that failed to detect the vulnerability on this particular portal that had not been patched. Both errors have since been addressed.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Smith">On July 29 and 30, the suspicious activity was detected. We followed our security incident response protocol at that time. The team immediately shut down the portal, and they began their internal security investigation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Smith">On August 2, we hired top cybersecurity forensic and legal experts. We also notified the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI). At that time, we did not know the nature or the scope of the incident. It was not until late August that we concluded that we had experienced a major data breach.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Smith">Over the weeks leading up to September 7, our team continued working around the clock to prepare to make things right. We took four steps to protect consumers: First, determining when and how to notify the public, relying on the advice of our experts that we needed to have a plan in place as soon as we announced; No. 2, helping consumers by developing a website, staffing up massive call centers, and offering free services not only to those impacted but to all Americans; No. 3, preparing for increased cyber attacks, which we were advised are common after a company announces a breach; and finally, No. 4, continuing to coordinate with the FBI in their criminal investigation of the hackers while at the same time notifying Federal and State agencies.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Smith">In the rollout of our remediation program, mistakes were made for which I am, again, deeply apologetic. I regret the frustration that many Americans felt when our websites and our call centers were overwhelmed in the early weeks. It is no excuse, but it certainly did not help that two of our larger call centers were shut down due to Hurricane Irma.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Smith">Since then, however, the company has dramatically increased its capacity. And I can report to you today that we have had over 420 million U.S. consumers visit our websites and that our call times, our wait times at the call centers have been reduced substantially.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Smith">At my direction, the company offered a broad package of services to all Americans, all of them free, aimed at protecting the consumers. In addition, we developed a new service available on January 31 of 2018 that will give all consumers the power to control access to their credit data by allowing them to lock and unlock access to their data for free for life, putting the power to control access to credit data in the hands of the American consumer. I am looking forward to discussing in as much detail as you would like that service offering during my testimony.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Smith">As we have all painfully learned, data security is a national security problem. Putting consumers in control of their credit data is a first step toward a long-term solution to the problem of identity theft.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Smith">But no single company can solve a larger problem on its own. I believe we need a private-public partnership to evaluate how to best protect Americans' personal data going forward, and I look forward to being a part of that dialog.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Smith">Chairman Hensarling, Ranking Member Waters, and honorable Members of the committee, thank you again for inviting me to speak today. I will close again by saying how sorry I am that this breach occurred on my watch.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Smith">On a personal note, I want to thank the many hardworking and dedicated employees that I worked with so tirelessly over the past 12 years. Equifax is a very good company with thousands of great people trying to do what is right every day. I know they will continue to work tirelessly as we have over the past few months to right the wrong.</paragraph>

<opening>[The prepared statement of Mr. Smith can be found on page</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="Mr. Smith can be found on pag"> Thank you. 64 of the Appendix.] </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Sherman</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Sherman"> Mr. Chairman, point of order. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Hensarling</speaker> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Chairman Hensarling"> The gentleman from California will state his point of order. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Sherman</speaker> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Sherman"> I would request that the witness be sworn. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Hensarling</speaker> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">It has not been the practice of the committee to swear in witnesses, as you know. The witness has to sign before coming here that the testimony will be truthful. That should be sufficient.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">The Chair yields himself 5 minutes for questions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">Mr. Smith, I know this is your fourth appearance before Congress, but I think you know it speaks to the gravity of the situation, the number of our constituents which are impacted and, frankly, the number of committee jurisdiction lines that this crosses.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">Since you have testified three other times, I will attempt to plow a little new ground. As you know, there is a lot of focus on--I guess to use your phrase--once the nature and the scope of the breach was realized, this still took approximately a month before people were notified of the breach.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Chairman Hensarling"> Did someone in law enforcement ask Equifax to delay notification to the public? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Smith</speaker> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Smith"> Mr. Chairman, as I mentioned in my written and oral comments, we were in communication routinely throughout the process with the FBI, but they did not necessarily dictate the flow of communication to the public. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Hensarling</speaker> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Chairman Hensarling"> OK. Were there outside data security consultants that advised the company to delay notification for a month? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Smith</speaker> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Smith">Mr. Chairman, we worked very closely with Mandiant--that may ring a bell. Mandiant is viewed as, if not the leading, one of the leading cyber forensic firms in our country--and our outside counsel, global law firm King & Spalding. And, yes, they both, in tandem with our team, managed the flow of communication externally.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Smith"> I would say, Mr. Chairman, one thing-- </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Hensarling</speaker> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Chairman Hensarling"> I am sorry.
